choices.text: Transverse perineal muscles
Transverse perineal branches of pudendal nerves

questions.text: All of the following structures are cut in mediolateral episiotomy except? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Obturator muscle

 

Explanation:

 

The obturator muscle is not cut in a mediolateral episiotomy. It is located deeper in the pelvis and is not involved in the incision made during this procedure.

 

Structures cut in a mediolateral episiotomy:

 

  • Posterior vaginal wall mucosa
  • Perineal muscles:
    • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles
    • Bulbospongiosus
    • Part of levator ani
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

 

Other options:

 

In a mediolateral episiotomy, the following structures are typically cut to facilitate childbirth:

 

Option A. Transverse perineal muscles: These include the superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles.

 

Option C. Bulbospongiosus: A muscle of the perineum that is also incised during the procedure.

 

Option D. Transverse perineal branches of pudendal nerves: These branches can be affected during the episiotomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a mediolateral episiotomy, various perineal structures, including the posterior vaginal wall mucosa, superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus, part of the levator ani, subcutaneous tissue, and skin, are incised. The obturator muscle is not involved in this procedure.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition Pg 649

questions.text: Which of the following lobes of the prostate forms the uvula vesicae? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Median

 

  • The uvula vesicae is formed by the prostate's median lobe.
  • The uvula vesicae is a slight elevation on the trigone immediately posterior to the urethral orifice caused by the median lobe of the prostate.
  • In benign prostatic hypertrophy, it is frequently enlarged.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior: The anterior lobe of the prostate, also referred to as the anterior fibromuscular stroma, is found at the front of the prostate, facing the pubic symphysis. Contrary to the other sections of the prostate, this area is primarily made up of fibromuscular tissue and contains fewer glandular elements. It doesn't commonly give rise to clinical conditions like benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) or prostate cancer.

 

Option B. Posterior: The posterior lobe is located at the back of the prostate, facing the rectum. This part of the prostate is significant clinically because it's the most common site for the development of prostate cancer. During a digital rectal exam, the physician can palpate this lobe, and any firm or irregular nodules felt here could suggest malignancy.

 

Option D. Lateral: The lateral lobes are the large bilateral portions of the prostate on either side of the urethra. These are the most voluminous parts of the prostate and are typically the primary sites involved in benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), a common condition in older men where the prostate enlarges and can cause urinary obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The middle lobe or median lobe of the prostate is situated between the ejaculatory ducts and the urethra. When the median lobe enlarges due to conditions like benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), it can project into the bladder, forming a structure called the "uvula vesicae." It is also known as Lietaud’s uvula. This growth can cause urinary symptoms by obstructing the bladder neck.

choices.text: Platelets is stored between 20°c to 24°C with a shelf life of 5 days
Cryoprecipitate is stored at -20°C with a shelf life of 6 months
Packed red cells stored with adenine, glucose, mannitol and saline is stored between -5°C to -15 °C with a shelf life of 5 weeks
Fresh frozen plasma is stored between -5°C to -15° C with a shelf life of 2 years

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about blood products? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Platelets is stored between 20° C to 24° C with a shelf life of 5 days

 

Platelets can be stored at temperatures ranging from 20°C to 24°C, and they have a shelf life of 5 days (with continuous agitation) 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cryoprecipitate is stored at -20°C with a shelf life of 6 months: This statement is incorrect because cryoprecipitate is typically stored at temperatures between -18°C to -30°C with a shelf life of 1 year. Cryoprecipitate is rich in clotting factors like fibrinogen, Factor VIII, and von Willebrand factor.

 

Option C. Packed red cells stored with adenine, glucose, mannitol, and saline is stored between -5°C to -15°C with a shelf life of 5 weeks: This statement is incorrect. Packed red blood cells stored with solutions like SAGM (Saline, Adenine, Glucose, Mannitol) are typically stored at temperatures between 2°C to 6°C, not -5°C to -15°C, and they have a shelf life of up to 42 days, not 5 weeks.

 

Option D. Fresh frozen plasma is stored between -5°C to -15°C with a shelf life of 2 years: This statement is incorrect. Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) is usually stored at temperatures between -18°C to -30°C and has a shelf life of 1 year.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-coagulants solution and shelf life

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presents with swelling in the right femur for 6 months. He complaints of severe pain in the thigh which dramatically improves with intake of aspirin. The biopsy image from the lesion is given below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteoid osteoma

 

  • This benign bone tumor is smaller in size, usually < 2 cm, and is commonly located in the cortex of long bones.
  • Femoral diaphysis is the most common location.
  • It is characterized histologically by a nidus surrounded by sclerotic bone.
  • A unique feature is that the pain worsens at night and gets a dramatic relief with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as aspirin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Osteosarcoma: A malignant tumor characterized by the direct formation of bone or osteoid tissue by tumor cells. It often appears in the metaphysis of long bones such as the femur, tibia, and humerus, primarily affecting children and young adults. Almost all patients with high-grade osteosarcoma report progressive pain. Night pain may be an important clue to the true diagnosis. May respond to NSAIDs like aspirin, but the response is often transient. Histologically, osteoid production from the tumor cells is seen. This osteoid matrix presents as calcification.

 

 

Option. C. Osteochondroma: A common benign bone growth that consists of a cartilage-capped bony projection or outgrowth on the surface of bones (exostosis). It typically arises from the metaphysis near the growth plate of long bones, particularly around the knee and shoulder. Usually asymptomatic, but may cause pain if the tumor becomes large or if it irritates nearby structures. Pathology and histology of an osteochondroma reveal a cap of benign hyaline cartilage resembling a disorganized growth plate, covered peripherally by perichondrium.

 

 

Option. D. Ewing's Sarcoma: A highly aggressive, malignant bone tumor that affects mostly children and adolescents. It can occur in any bone but is most often found in long bones and the pelvic region. Histologically, it features small, round, blue cells. Typically presents with pain, swelling, and a palpable mass. May respond to NSAIDs, but the response is often transient.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The distinctive clinical presentation of relief with aspirin strongly points to an osteoid osteoma, especially when correlated with the biopsy findings suggestive of this benign condition.

questions.text: Which Biochemical method is exploited for monoclonal antibody production by hybridoma technique?  (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Purine salvage pathway

 

Hybridoma technology → common methods used to produce monoclonal antibodies

 

In this process, antibody-producing B-lymphocytes are isolated from mice after immunizing the mice with specific antigen and are fused with immortal myeloma cell lines to form hybrid cells, called hybridoma cell lines.

 

 

  • Even the most efficient fusion method will give only 1 to 2% of fused and viable hybridoma cells.
  • Hybridoma selection involve screening of the fused cells from the unfused cells. It is done using HAT media (a selection media).
  • HAT medium contains Hypoxanthine-Aminopterin-Thymidine. The trick is that Aminopterin inhibits DHFR. So, it inhibits de-novo purine synthesis. Inhibition of DHFR also inhibits conversion of dUMP to dTMP.
  • Salvage pathway will occur, but only in B-cells, not myeloma cells. Myeloma cells are deficient in HGPRT .
  • Hypoxanthine and deoxythymidine allow cells with functional hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) genes to survive through salvage pathways.
  • Due to a limited life span, unfused B cells perish within a few days.
  • Unfused malignant neoplastic cells die as a result of the lack of HGPRT gene
  • Therefore, the remaining viable cells left in the media are the hybrid cells; these hybrid cells have the ability to grow and divide on HAT media because they have functional HGPRT gene from B lymphocytes

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycolytic pathway: This pathway is involved in the breakdown of glucose to pyruvate for energy production and is not specifically exploited in hybridoma technology for monoclonal antibody production.

 

Option B. Pentose Phosphate pathway: This pathway generates NADPH and ribose-5-phosphate for nucleotide synthesis but is not the key pathway exploited in the hybridoma technique.

 

Option C. Kreb’s cycle: This cycle is part of cellular respiration and energy production but is not directly involved in the selection process of hybridoma cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The purine salvage pathway is critical in hybridoma technology for monoclonal antibody production, enabling the selection of viable hybridoma cells in HAT medium.

questions.text: Identify the plant given in the image below? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Argemone Mexicana

 

  • The plant in the image is Argemone Mexicana.
  • It is also called as Mexican prickly poppy.
  • Oil extract can cause Epidemic dropsy characterized by vomiting, diarrhea, edema of the feet, and generalized anasarca.
  • Identification: Yellow flowers

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Datura alba: Datura alba, also known as white datura, has large trumpet-shaped white flowers and is a different plant with its own toxic properties, primarily affecting the nervous system.

 

 

Option C. Abrus precatorius: Abrus precatorius, commonly known as Rosary pea or jequirity, has distinctive red seeds with a black spot. The plant is different from Argemone mexicana.

 

 

Option D. Erthyroxylum coca: Erthyroxylum coca is the plant from which cocaine is derived. It has small white flowers and red berries, and does not resemble Argemone mexicana.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The plant Argemone mexicana, identifiable by its yellow flowers and spiny leaves, is known for its toxic oil extract which can cause Epidemic dropsy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Thoracoscore? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Complication of Surgery

 

This is not a component of Thoracoscore. While complications of surgery can impact outcomes, they are not a predefined parameter in the Thoracoscore risk model.

 

The complication of surgery is not a component of Thoracoscore.

 

Thoracoscore is a risk model used to predict the probability of death within 30 days following thoracic surgery. The model takes into account the following nine parameters:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Performance status: This is a component of Thoracoscore. Poorer performance status is associated with a higher risk.

 

Option C. ASA grading: This is a component of Thoracoscore. The ASA score is used to assess the physical status and associated risk of patients undergoing surgery.

 

Option D. Priority of surgery: This is a component of Thoracoscore. The urgency of the surgery (elective vs. emergent) affects the risk of postoperative complications and mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thoracoscore is a predictive risk model for mortality within 30 days following thoracic surgery. It includes parameters such as age, sex, performance status, dyspnea score, ASA score, cardiovascular comorbidity, surgical procedure extent, cancer status, and urgency of surgery, but does not include the complication of surgery as a predefined parameter.

questions.text: The following image is caused by infection with which virus? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CMV

 

The given image shows owl's eye inclusion bodies (intranuclear basophilic inclusions) which is characteristically seen in CMV infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. HPV: Incorrect. Human papillomavirus (HPV) infections are characterized by koilocytes, which have a perinuclear halo and wrinkled nuclei. They do not show owl's eye inclusion bodies.

 

Option C. HIV: Incorrect. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) does not produce owl's eye inclusion bodies. HIV is typically diagnosed with serological tests and does not produce specific histopathological features like CMV.

 

Option D. EBV: Incorrect. Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infections are associated with atypical lymphocytes, also known as Downey cells. They do not produce owl's eye inclusion bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Owl's eye inclusion bodies, which are intranuclear basophilic inclusions, are characteristic of CMV infection. This feature helps distinguish CMV from other viral infections in histopathological examinations.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs promotes bone formation? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Teriparatide
 

  • Teriparatide is recombinant PTH analogue that is used in the treatment of osteoporosis. When given in low doses, it stimulates bone formation by mimicking the physiological action of PTH on the osteoblasts.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Calcitonin: Mechanism: Calcitonin inhibits osteoclast activity, reducing bone resorption. It helps maintain bone density but does not stimulate new bone formation.

 

Options B. Raloxifene: Mechanism: Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM). It inhibits bone resorption by reducing osteoclast activity and is used to prevent bone loss in postmenopausal women, but it does not promote bone formation.

 

Options C. Bisphosphonates: Mechanism: Bisphosphonates, such as alendronate and risedronate, inhibit osteoclast-mediated bone resorption. These drugs help maintain bone density and reduce the risk of fractures, but they do not promote new bone formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DRUGS USED IN OSTEOPOROSIS

questions.text: A mentally challenged female requires consent for MTP. The consent can be given to her by:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Legal guardian

 

Explanation:

 

In the case of a mentally challenged female requiring consent for Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP), the consent must be given by her legal guardian.

 

According to Indian law, consent from a guardian is required in two situations:

 

  1. If the person seeking MTP is below 18 years of age.
  2. If the person seeking MTP is mentally challenged.

 

In other cases, the consent of a guardian is not mandatory.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Husband/Partner: While it is advisable to obtain consent from the husband or partner to avoid potential divorce proceedings, it is not a legal requirement for MTP.

 

Option. C. Herself: A mentally challenged female is not considered capable of giving informed consent for MTP.

 

Option. D. Magistrate: A magistrate's consent is not required for MTP in the case of a mentally challenged female.

 

Additional information:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the case of a mentally challenged female requiring consent for MTP, the consent must be provided by her legal guardian, as she is not considered capable of giving informed consent herself.

questions.text: Components of Disaster cycle that can be included in the recovery phase are: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Response – Rehabilitation – Reconstruction

 

 

The disaster cycle consists of several phases: impact, response, rehabilitation, reconstruction, mitigation, and preparedness.

 

The recovery phase specifically focuses on restoring the affected area to normalcy and includes three key components: Response, Rehabilitation, and Reconstruction (Mnemonic: 3Rs). These steps are crucial for rebuilding after a disaster, addressing immediate needs (response), restoring essential services (rehabilitation), and rebuilding infrastructure (reconstruction).

 

Educational Objective:
 

The recovery phase of the disaster cycle includes the components of Response, Rehabilitation, and Reconstruction, which are essential for restoring the community post-disaster.

questions.text: Identify the type of joint marked in the image: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Saddle

 

  • The marked joint in the image is the incudo-malleolar joint, which is a type of saddle joint. This joint is located in the middle ear and involves the malleus and incus bones. The mnemonic "SBI" helps remember the types of joints in relation to the incus:
    • S for Saddle joint (incudo-malleolar joint)
    • B for Ball and socket joint (incudo-stapedial joint)
    • I for the Incus, positioned in front and behind the respective joints.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ball and socket: Incorrect. The ball and socket joint is found in the incudo-stapedial joint, not the incudo-malleolar joint.

 

Option C. Plane: Incorrect. The plane joint is not represented in the middle ear ossicles.

 

Option D. Gliding: Incorrect. Gliding joints are not present in the middle ear ossicles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The incudo-malleolar joint is a saddle joint, an important anatomical feature in the middle ear.

questions.text: Which of the following factor is not derived from an ABG analysis directly? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bicarbonate

 

Explanation:

 

Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis is a critical test in clinical settings that measures the levels of oxygen (PO2), carbon dioxide (PCO2), and the pH of the blood. These parameters are directly measured by the ABG machine. However, bicarbonate (HCO3-) is not directly measured by the ABG machine; instead, it is calculated using the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation, which involves the measured pH and PCO2 values.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. PO2: The partial pressure of oxygen (PO2) is directly measured by the ABG machine, providing vital information about oxygenation status.

 

Option C. PCO2: The partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PCO2) is also directly measured by the ABG machine and indicates the level of CO2 in the blood, reflecting respiratory function.

 

Option D. pH: The pH level of the blood, which indicates its acidity or alkalinity, is directly measured by the ABG machine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ABG analysis measures the levels of oxygen (PO2), carbon dioxide (PCO2), and the pH of the blood, not bicarbonate.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl went out playing. After coming home, she looked confused. Parents brought her to the hospital, and on examination, she looked irritable and has not passed urine since morning. Her friends said she had something while playing. Which of the following is the likely intoxication and the correct antidote? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Datura; Physostigmine

 

The clinical presentation suggests anticholinergic toxicity, characterized by confusion, irritability, and urinary retention. Datura, commonly known as jimsonweed or thorn apple, contains tropane alkaloids like atropine, scopolamine, and hyoscyamine, which cause anticholinergic symptoms.

 

Anticholinergic toxicity manifests with:

 

  • Central nervous system effects: confusion, hallucinations, irritability
  • Peripheral effects: dry mouth, urinary retention, constipation, tachycardia, hyperthermia

 

The appropriate antidote for anticholinergic toxicity is a cholinergic drug like physostigmine, which increases the levels of acetylcholine by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Yellow oleander; Physostigmine: Yellow oleander poisoning involves cardiac glycosides similar to digoxin, which can cause bradycardia, hyperkalemia, and gastrointestinal symptoms. The antidote for oleander poisoning is Digibind, not physostigmine.

 

Option B. Datura; Digibind: While datura poisoning is correctly identified here, Digibind is the antidote for digoxin or digitalis toxicity, not anticholinergic toxicity caused by datura.

 

Option C. Yellow oleander; Digibind: This option correctly pairs yellow oleander poisoning with its antidote, Digibind. However, the clinical presentation does not fit yellow oleander poisoning, which typically involves bradycardia and gastrointestinal symptoms rather than confusion and urinary retention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Datura poisoning causes anticholinergic toxicity, characterized by confusion, urinary retention, and other anticholinergic symptoms. The antidote for such toxicity is physostigmine, a cholinergic agent that increases acetylcholine levels by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase.

questions.text: Identify the type of ulcer. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trophic ulcer

 

The image shows an ulcer on the sole of the foot with a characteristic appearance. It is surrounded by a white area due to callosities, indicating chronic pressure. This description is typical of a trophic ulcer, also known as a neuropathic ulcer. These ulcers occur in areas of the body subjected to prolonged pressure, often in patients with peripheral neuropathy. The lack of sensation leads to repeated trauma and subsequent ulceration, which is commonly seen in the weight-bearing areas such as the soles of the feet.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arterial ulcer: Arterial ulcers are typically located on the distal parts of the body such as the tips of toes and feet. They are often painful, with a "punched-out" appearance and a well-defined border. They usually have minimal exudate and occur due to inadequate blood supply.

 

Option B. Venous ulcer: Venous ulcers generally occur on the lower legs, particularly around the medial malleolus. They have irregular borders, are usually surrounded by hyperpigmentation, and are associated with chronic venous insufficiency. These ulcers are often exudative and less painful compared to arterial ulcers.

 

Option D. Diabetic ulcer: While diabetic ulcers can have a neuropathic component, they are a more complex condition with additional ischemic and infectious components. They are not exclusively located on pressure points and can appear anywhere on the foot. The distinguishing factor for trophic ulcers is their location on weight-bearing areas with surrounding callosities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trophic (neuropathic) ulcers typically occur in weight-bearing areas, such as the soles of the feet, and are surrounded by callosities. They are primarily seen in patients with peripheral neuropathy, where lack of sensation leads to repeated trauma and ulceration. Recognizing this type of ulcer is crucial for appropriate management and prevention of further complications.

questions.text: Patient came with fever, rash and eschar formation. On examination, mite bite was also present. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scrub typhus

 

Explanation:

 

The key points that support this diagnosis are:

 

  1. The presence of eschar, which is a common finding in scrub typhus and anthrax.
  2. The mite bite, which is the biggest clue provided, as scrub typhus is transmitted by the bite of larval mites (chiggers).
  3. The explanation that among the rickettsial diseases mentioned in the options (scrub typhus, Rocky Mountain spotted fever, and epidemic typhus), only scrub typhus is transmitted by mites.

 

Scrub typhus is a rickettsial disease caused by the bacteria Orientia tsutsugamushi and transmitted by the bite of larval mites, commonly known as chiggers.

 

Triad – Eschar; Regional lymphadenopathy and Maculopapular rash

 

 

 

 

*Coxiella and  Bartonella  are now excluded from this family

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anthrax: Anthrax is caused by the bacteria Bacillus anthracis and is not transmitted by mite bites. It is a zoonotic disease acquired through contact with infected animals or their products, inhalation of spores, or ingestion of contaminated food.

 

Option C. Rocky Mountain spotted fever: This is another rickettsial disease, but it is transmitted by ticks, not mites. The presence of a mite bite in the given scenario rules out this option.

 

Option D. Epidemic Typhus: Caused by Rickettsia prowazekii and transmitted by lice, epidemic typhus presents with a rash but does not typically include eschar formation, nor is it associated with mite bites.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scrub typhus is a rickettsial disease caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi and transmitted by the bite of larval mites (chiggers). The presence of eschar, fever, rash, and a mite bite are key clinical features suggestive of this diagnosis.

questions.text: 22-year-old patient with high myopia and thick glasses presents with floaters in his eyes. What is the cause of this condition? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Retinal detachment

 

Retinal detachment occurs when the sensory retina separates from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium. This separation can be due to a retinal break, known as rhegmatogenous retinal detachment, which is the most common type. In patients with high myopia, there is an increased risk of peripheral retinal degeneration, leading to retinal holes that can progress to retinal detachment. The presence of floaters and flashes is a key symptom indicating retinal detachment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subarachnoid hemorrhage: This condition typically presents with sudden severe headache and neurological symptoms rather than visual symptoms like floaters.

 

Option C. Vitreous hemorrhage: While this can cause floaters, it is more commonly associated with trauma, diabetic retinopathy, or vascular abnormalities rather than high myopia.

 

Option D. Branched retinal artery occlusion: This condition usually presents with sudden, painless loss of vision in part of the visual field rather than floaters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with high myopia are at increased risk for peripheral retinal degeneration and subsequent retinal detachment, presenting with symptoms like floaters and flashes.

questions.text: A man on diuretics presents with weakness. An ECG was done which showed flat T waves and prominent U waves. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hypokalemia

 

Hypokalemia is a condition characterized by low potassium levels in the blood, which can occur in patients taking diuretics. Diuretics increase the excretion of potassium in the urine, leading to its depletion. The triad of ECG changes associated with hypokalemia are distinctive and include:

 

  1. Flattening of T waves: This is often the earliest change observed in hypokalemia.
  2. Prominent U waves: These waves become more visible as the potassium levels drop further.
  3. ST depression: This can occur in more severe cases of hypokalemia.

 

These ECG changes are due to the altered repolarization of the heart muscle cells caused by low potassium levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperkalemia: Hyperkalemia, or high potassium levels, typically presents with different ECG changes, such as tall, peaked T waves, wide QRS complexes, and possibly absent P waves. These findings are not consistent with the patient's ECG.

 

Option C. Hypomagnesemia: While low magnesium can cause ECG changes and muscle weakness, the specific ECG findings in this case (flat T waves and prominent U waves) are more indicative of hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Hypernatremia: High sodium levels do not typically cause specific ECG changes. Severe hypernatremia might cause cerebral edema and nonspecific T wave inversions, but it does not lead to the characteristic ECG findings seen with hypokalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypokalemia is characterized by ECG changes such as flattened T waves, prominent U waves, and ST depression. It is commonly seen in patients on diuretics, and recognizing these ECG patterns is crucial for diagnosis and management.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is not involved in the overhead abduction of the arm? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Pectoralis major

 

  • Pectoralis major is mainly involved in flexion, adduction and medial rotation of the arm (at the shoulder joint) and is not involved in the abduction of the arm.
  • Glenohumeral abduction is about 120° or more. The glenohumeral arthrodesis restricts the abduction at about 45°. Further abduction occurs at the sterno- and acromioclavicular articulations, and contralateral vertebral flexion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serratus Anterior: The serratus anterior muscle is involved in the overhead abduction of the arm. This muscle helps in the upward rotation of the scapula, allowing the arm to be raised overhead.

 

Option B. Deltoid: The deltoid muscle is a key muscle for overhead abduction of the arm. It has three distinct portions (anterior, middle, and posterior) that cover the shoulder joint. The middle portion of the deltoid is particularly responsible for abduction of the arm, lifting it away from the body.

 

Option C. Trapezius: The trapezius muscle also plays a role in the overhead abduction of the arm. The upper fibers of the trapezius assist in elevating the shoulder girdle, contributing to arm abduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PRINCIPLE MUSCLES ACTING ON SHOULDERS

choices.text: Help with PET scan units for diagnosis of cancer

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about cancer treatment according to the Colombo plan? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Setting up cobalt therapy units

 

The Colombo Plan, established in 1950, was drawn up for the cooperative economic development of South and South-East Asia. It included 20 countries with the main aim of improving the living standards of people. The plan focused on industrial and agricultural development and provided support for health promotion, mostly through fellowships.

 

Key Contributions of the Colombo Plan:

 

  • AIIMS, New Delhi: Established with financial assistance from New Zealand.
  • Cobalt Therapy Units: Canada supplied cobalt therapy units to medical institutions in India as part of the Colombo Plan. These units significantly enhanced the capabilities for cancer treatment in India.

 

Cobalt Therapy Units:

 

  • Cobalt Therapy: Involves using gamma rays from cobalt-60 isotopes to treat cancer. It was a crucial development in radiotherapy in the mid-20th century and improved cancer treatment outcomes significantly.
  • Provision under Colombo Plan: The supply of cobalt therapy units by Canada helped Indian medical institutions upgrade their cancer treatment facilities, making advanced radiotherapy accessible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under the Colombo Plan, Canada supplied cobalt therapy units to medical institutions in India, significantly enhancing the country's capacity to provide advanced cancer treatment through radiotherapy. This was a crucial step in improving healthcare infrastructure and cancer treatment capabilities in India.

questions.text: A patient has a field defect where he cannot see the left side from the left eye and the left side from the right eye, that is from both the eyes the patient is not able to look towards the left, with preserved central vision. What is the field defect?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing

 

Explanation:

 

Homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing is a type of visual field defect where the patient cannot see the same side of the visual field in both eyes, but central vision is preserved.

 

This condition typically indicates a lesion in the occipital lobe, specifically on the side opposite to the visual field loss. In this case, the patient cannot see the left side from both eyes, which means the lesion is in the right occipital lobe. The occipital lobe processes visual information, and a lesion here can result in loss of vision in the corresponding visual field of both eyes.

 

Macular sparing occurs because the macular region of the occipital cortex has a dual blood supply from both the middle cerebral artery and the posterior cerebral artery, providing some redundancy that preserves central vision even when other parts of the occipital lobe are damaged.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Quadrantanopia: This refers to the loss of vision in one quadrant (one-fourth) of the visual field. It is not consistent with the described field defect involving half of the visual field.

 

Option C. Homonymous hemianopia: This is the loss of the same half of the visual field in both eyes without the specification of macular sparing. The inclusion of macular sparing helps to localize the lesion more specifically to the occipital lobe.

 

Option D. Bitemporal hemianopia: This is the loss of the outer (temporal) visual fields in both eyes, typically due to a lesion at the optic chiasm. It does not fit the description where the same side of the visual field is lost in both eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing indicates a lesion in the occipital lobe on the side opposite to the visual field.

choices.text: OCP + Anti androgen
Counsel for metabolic syndrome

questions.text: A young girl presents with menstrual irregularity, acne, increased hair growth with a Ferriman Gallway score of 6, and a BMI of 29. Her mother has diabetes. Which is not a management option?  (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) OCP + Anti androgen

 

Explanation:

 

Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are commonly used alone for managing symptoms like acne and menstrual irregularity in PCOS. The addition of anti-androgens is typically reserved for cases where OCPs alone do not manage hirsutism effectively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. OCP: OCPs are a standard treatment for managing menstrual irregularities and hyperandrogenism.

 

Option C. Yoga + Exercise: Yoga and exercise are recommended for weight management and improving insulin sensitivity.

 

Option D. Counsel for metabolic syndrome: Counseling for metabolic syndrome is crucial given her high BMI and family history of diabetes.

 

Educational objective:

 

In managing PCOS-like symptoms, initial treatment often starts with OCPs. Additional treatments like anti-androgens are considered if initial treatments are insufficient. Lifestyle modifications are always beneficial.

questions.text: Identify the structure given in the image: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Incus

 

The structure given in the image is the incus.

 

The malleus has head, neck, handle (manubrium), a lateral and an anterior process. Head and neck of malleus lie in the attic. Manubrium is embedded in the fibrous layer of the tympanic membrane. The lateral process forms a knob-like projection on the outer surface of the tympanic membrane and gives attachment to the anterior and posterior malleolar folds.

 

The incus has a body and a short process, both of which lie in the attic, and a long process which hangs vertically and attaches to the head of stapes.

 

The stapes has a head, neck, anterior and posterior crura, and a footplate. The footplate is held in the oval window by annular ligament.


Other Options:

 

Option A. The malleus is the largest ossicle and is shaped like a mallet. The parts of the malleus are the head, neck, handle (manubrium), and anterior and lateral processes. The head and neck lie in the attic.

 

The tympanic membrane is connected to the handle of the malleus.

 

Option C. The stapes has a head, neck, footplate, and anterior and posterior crura. The annular ligament holds the footplate of stapes in the oval window.

 

 

The joints between the ear ossicles are synovial joints. A saddle-shaped joint is present between the incus and malleus. Incus and stapes articulate via a ball and socket joint.

 

Options D. Vomer A facial bone forming part of the nasal septum, unrelated to the middle ear.

Educational Objective:

 

The incus is one of the three auditory ossicles in the middle ear. It plays a critical role in hearing by transmitting sound vibrations from the malleus to the stapes.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 9

questions.text: The test kit shown in the image below works on the principle of: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immunochromatography

 

The above image shows a HbsAg card test kit which works on the principle of immunochromatography.

 

The immunochromatographic membrane is used for antigen detection, while a nitrocellulose membrane is used to absorb the antigen from a specimen. A coloured reaction appears directly on the membrane with the sequential addition of conjugate followed by the substrate. In some cases, the antigen is captured by a bound antibody directed against the antigen. These assays have the advantage of being rapid and also frequently include a built-in internal control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ELISA (Enzyme-linked Immunosorbent Assay): Uses enzyme-labeled antibodies and an enzymatic reaction to produce a detectable signal, usually a color change, and typically requires more time and equipment to perform.

 

Option C. Immunofluorescence: Involves the use of fluorescent-labeled antibodies to detect specific antigens or antibodies in a sample, requiring specialized equipment to visualize fluorescence.

 

Option D. Chemiluminescence: Relies on a chemical reaction that produces light to detect antigens or antibodies, also requiring specialized equipment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immunochromatographic tests, such as the HbsAg card test, provide a rapid, user-friendly, and effective means of testing for certain antigens or antibodies directly at the point of care. Their simplicity and speed make them invaluable tools in clinical settings, especially where quick decision-making is crucial.

questions.text: A 24-year-old lactating female with an 18-month-old child comes with a history of irregular, heavy bleeding seeking contraceptive advice. Which is the contraceptive of choice? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) levonorgesterel IUD

 

Explanation:

 

  • Suitable during lactation
    • LNG-IUS is a progestin-only method
    • Does not reduce milk production (unlike estrogen-containing pills)
  • Controls heavy menstrual bleeding (menorrhagia)
    • LNG-IUS reduces menstrual blood loss by 70–90%
    • Improves hemoglobin levels and quality of life
  • Long-acting and reversible
    • Provides effective contraception for up to 5 years
    • Fertility returns quickly after removal
  • Low maintenance
    • No daily action required
    • Ideal for busy mothers with young children
  • High efficacy
    • Failure rate <0.2% per year
    • One of the most effective reversible methods
  • WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC)
    • Category 1 (no restriction) after 6 weeks postpartum
    • Safe for breastfeeding women
  • Fewer systemic side effects
    • Hormone acts locally in the uterus
    • Minimal systemic absorption

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Copper-T 380A: Copper-T 380A is a non-hormonal intrauterine device that may exacerbate heavy menstrual bleeding and would not be suitable for a patient already experiencing heavy bleeding.

 

Option C. Mala N: Mala N is also a possible contraceptive in this situation. There is high chance of non compliance and missed pill. LNG IUS is better option in such cases

 

Option D. Norethisterone enanthate - depot injection: Norethisterone enanthate is a progesterone-only injectable contraceptive. it may lead to delay in return to menses, and also requires follow up every 3 months for next dose, which is inconvenient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a lactating woman with a history of irregular and heavy menstrual bleeding, a combined oral contraceptive pill (COC) like Mala N is the preferred choice after the first 6 months postpartum as it helps regulate menstrual cycles and reduce menstrual flow.

 

Ref: Page no 398, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 7th edition

questions.text: Identify the marked area in the given spirometry graph?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Functional residual capacity

 

Explanation:

 

The marked area in the spirometry graph indicates the Functional Residual Capacity (FRC). FRC is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal, passive exhalation. This is not fully expelled during a standard tidal cycle and represents the air that remains in the lungs to keep them inflated.

 

  • FRC Components:
    • FRC includes the Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) plus the Residual Volume (RV).
    • ERV is the additional air that can be forcibly exhaled after the end of a normal, calm exhalation.
    • RV is the volume of air still remaining in the lungs after the most forceful exhalation, which cannot be voluntarily expelled.

 

 

Significance in Spirometry:

 

In spirometry:

 

  • FRC is critical for maintaining the alveolar inflation and preventing the airways from collapsing.
  • It is not directly measurable by simple spirometry because it includes the residual volume. Techniques such as body plethysmography or using tracer gas dilution methods are usually employed to measure FRC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tidal Volume (TV or VT): This is the volume of air inhaled or exhaled during a normal breathing cycle, not indicated in this context.

 

Option C. Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV): Part of FRC, this is the maximum volume of air that can be voluntarily expelled after the end of a normal, passive exhalation.

 

Option D. Expiratory Capacity: It is the total amount of air that can be expired from the lungs after a maximal inhalation, typically including the tidal volume plus the expiratory reserve volume, not specifically marked here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal expiration and is essential for preventing lung collapse and maintaining pulmonary function, especially during physical activities or respiratory challenges. Understanding FRC's role helps in assessing lung health and diagnosing potential respiratory disorders.

questions.text: 3-point bony relationship is maintained in which fracture?(INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Supracondylar humerus fracture

 

THREE POINT BONY LANDMARKS IN ELBOW

 

  • Tips of medial and lateral epicondyles and olecranon
  • Form isosceles triangle with elbow in 90° flexion
  • Lie transversely in straight line in elbow extension

 

 

  • Three-point bony relationship is not disturbed in fracture supracondylar humerus as the fracture occurs above the level of these bony landmarks.
  • With disturbed (increased) intercondylar distance: 
    • Fracture lateral epicondyle and condyle
    • Fracture medial epicondyle and condyle
    • Fracture intercondylar humerus.
  • With maintained intercondylar distance: 
    • Fracture olecranon (i.e. upper end ulna)
    • Elbow dislocation (classical example)
  • Waeak posterior capsule may disrupt three-point bony relation by promoting subluxation or dislocations of elbow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elbow dislocation. In elbow dislocation, the intercondylar distance is maintained but the three-point bony relationship is disturbed.

 

Option C. Intercondylar humerus fracture. In this fracture, the intercondylar distance is disturbed i.e., increased, so is the three-point bony relationship.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The three-point bony relationship of the elbow is maintained only in the supracondylar humerus fracture because this fracture occurs above the bony landmarks associated with the relation.

choices.text: Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady presents with third degree uterine prolapse. Which of the following is the best management for her?( NEET PG 2019 )
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair

 

Explanation

 

  • In the given case scenario, vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair is the ideal management.
  • This is also called as Ward Mayo repair
  • This is recommended to patients who satisfy the following criteria:
    • >40 years of age
    • Have completed their families
    • Do not wish to preserve menstrual and child-bearing function

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fothergill repair: This is also known as Manchester repair and involves conserving the uterus. In this procedure, cervical amputation with plication of the cardinal ligaments is done. It is done in young women who have completed their families with utero-vaginal prolapse.

 

Option B. Sling operation: This is preferred in women who are young, nulliparous (yet to have children/ complete their families) with prolapse

 

Option D. Shirodkar procedure: This is a modification of Manchester/ Fothergill surgery and does not include cervical amputation

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair (Ward Mayo repair) is the preferred management for older women (>40 years) with third degree uterine prolapse who have completed their families and do not wish to preserve menstrual and child-bearing function.

 

Ref: Page 221, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Match the following molecules with their carriers in plasma: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

 

Plasma contains various components like ions, inorganic and organic molecules that help in the transport of substances across various parts of the body, such as Albumin, globulin, and fibrinogen fractions.

 

  1. Thyroxine is carried by transthyretin, also called thyroid-binding pre-albumin.
  2. Fatty acids are carried by albumin, which is a major carrier protein and osmotic regulator. It also transports hormones, amino acids, vitamins, and steroids.
  3. Hemoglobin binds to haptoglobin, which prevents free hemoglobin from being excreted in the urine.
  4. Heme binds with hemopexin for heme recycling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plasma transporters like prealbumin, albumin, haptoglobin, and hemopexin play crucial roles in the transport and recycling of thyroxine, fatty acids, hemoglobin, and heme respectively.

questions.text: Which of the following cerclage procedures would be done in a nonpregnant female? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lash and Lash cerclage

 

Explanation:

 

  • Lash and Lash procedure is the only cerclage procedure that is done in the non-pregnant state. Vaginal procedures are preferred over laparoscopic procedure

 

Types of Cerclage Procedures (Other Options)

 

  1. Transvaginal
  2. Transabdominal

 

1. Transvaginal

 

  • McDonald suture
    • Purse string
    • Below the level of the internal os
    • Placed during pregnancy (12-14 weeks
    • Sutures removed at 37 weeks

 

 

  • Shirodkar cerclage
    • Placed during pregnancy (!2-14 weeks)
    • Bladder pushed up
    • Closer to internal os
    • More physiological than McDonald
    • Usually done if previous failed McDonald
    • A tape is inserted circumferentially near the os
    • Removed at 37 weeks

 

 

  • Wurm’s Cerclage
    • 2 sutures taken as shown in figure
    • Placed during pregnancy at 12-14 weeks
    • Removed at 37 weeks

 

 

  • Lash Cerclage
    • Done PRE-PREGNANCY
    • A defect in cervix is removed and cervix reconstructed
    • Deliver is ALWAYS by LSCS
    • Sutures not removed

 

 

2. Transabdominal:

 

  1. Could be done by laparotomy (1st introduced by Benson and Durfee) OR by Laparoscopy
  2. Preferably done pre-pregnancy but can also be done during pregnancy
  3. Done in cases of failed transvaginal cerclage procedures.
  4. Most physiological as it is highest (at the level of the cervix)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Lash and Lash cerclage is the only cerclage procedure done in a nonpregnant female.

questions.text: Which of the following emergency contraceptive is used in India? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg


In India, Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg is commonly used as an emergency contraceptive. This medication is effective when taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse. It works primarily by inhibiting or delaying ovulation, thus preventing pregnancy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Misoprostol 400 mcg: Incorrect. Misoprostol is used for medical abortion and does not serve as an emergency contraceptive.

 

Option B. Ethinyl estradiol 600 mcg: Incorrect. Ethinyl estradiol is used in combined oral contraceptive pills, but it is not commonly used alone for emergency contraception. The Yuzpe regimen, which includes ethynyl estradiol, is less commonly used compared to levonorgestrel.

 

Option C. Ulipristal 30 mg: Incorrect. Ulipristal acetate (30 mg) is a selective progesterone receptor modulator used as an emergency contraceptive, but it is not as widely available or commonly used in India as levonorgestrel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg is the emergency contraceptive used in India.

 

Ref: Page no 243, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology 15th edition

questions.text: Identify the rules used as tests of insanity? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Both A and B

 

  • Durham's rule and Curren's rule are used in cases as tests for insanity.

  • The Durham's rule states, “an accused is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act was the product of mental disease or mental defect”.

  • The Curren's rule states that “an accused person will not be criminally responsible, if at the time of committing the act, he did not have the capacity to regulate his conduct to the requirements of law, as a result of mental disease or defect”.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Both Durham's rule and Curren's rule are significant tests used to determine criminal responsibility in cases where the defendant's mental state is in question.

questions.text: All of the following conditions are associated with Metastatic calcification except: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin D deficiency

 

Metastatic calcification is associated with Hypercalcemia (Vitamin D toxicity), not Vitamin D deficiency.

 

 

Tumors having Dystrophic calcification: Psammoma bodies present

 

M – Meningioma, Mesothelioma

 

O – Ovary (Serous cystadenoma)

 

S – Salivary gland tumor

 

T – Thyroid (Papillary thyroid cancer)

 

P – Prolactinoma

 

G – Glucagonoma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal failure: Chronic kidney disease can lead to secondary hyperparathyroidism and hyperphosphatemia, both of which contribute to hypercalcemia and subsequent metastatic calcification.

 

Option B. Accumulation of calcium phosphate: This typically occurs in the context of renal failure or parathyroid hormone-related issues, leading to metastatic calcification.

 

Option D Parathyroid activation secretion: Hyperparathyroidism, whether primary or secondary, causes an increase in serum calcium, leading to metastatic calcification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metastatic calcification is associated with conditions that lead to hypercalcemia, not with conditions that result in normal or low calcium levels, such as Vitamin D deficiency.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with abdominal pain, vomiting, oliguria, and periorbital puffiness following chemotherapy. Investigations reveal hyperuricemia and hyperkalemia. What is the next best step in the management of this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydration

 

The clinical scenario and the laboratory investigations are suggestive of tumor lysis syndrome. Aggressive hydration is the next best step in the management of this condition.

 

  • Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) can occur after chemotherapy due to release of intracellular components.
  • Increased uric acid levels cause hyperuricemia, while release of potassium and phosphate leads to hyperkalemia and hyperphosphatemia.
  • Hyperphosphatemia leads to reciprocal depression of serum calcium causing hypocalcemia.
  • TLS can result in renal failure due to deposition of uric acid crystals, calcium phosphate, and hyperphosphatemia.
  • Signs and symptoms of TLS include abdominal pain, dysuria, oliguria, flank pain, anorexia, vomiting, cramps, seizures, altered mental status, tetany, weakness, and paralysis.
  • The Cairo-Bishop criteria are used to assess the severity of TLS.
  • Management of TLS includes measuring electrolytes and aggressive hydration before starting therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Probenecid: Probenecid inhibits the organic anion transporter in the nephron, thereby inhibiting the reabsorption of uric acid. However, it is contraindicated in TLS as it increases the risk of uric acid stones due to increased uric acid levels.

 

Option C. Allopurinol: Allopurinol and febuxostat are xanthine oxidase inhibitors that decrease uric acid synthesis and treat hyperuricemia. While they are useful in managing hyperuricemia, aggressive hydration is the first-line treatment in TLS to prevent renal failure.

 

Option D. Rasburicase: Rasburicase is an enzyme that degrades uric acid and is preferred in TLS over allopurinol for rapidly reducing uric acid levels. However, initial aggressive hydration is crucial before administering rasburicase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aggressive hydration is the first-line management for tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) to prevent renal failure and facilitate the excretion of released intracellular components.

questions.text: What is the proper disposal method for a damaged vaccine vial according to biomedical waste management protocols? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Puncture proof blue bin 

 

Blue puncture proof container

 

Under BMW guidelines, Glassware and Metallic Body Implants are disposed in Cardboard boxes with blue colored marking/ puncture proof bins. These bins are specifically designed to safely handle glass and metallic body implants to prevent injury and ensure proper disposal.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: An 8-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain and vomiting. The child's parents mention that the pain has been increasing over the past few hours. On examination, the child appears distressed and has abdominal tenderness. An X-ray is ordered, and it reveals a gasless abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Acute Pancreatitis

 

  • A gasless abdomen is seen in acute pancreatitis.
  • Acute pancreatitis is an inflammation of the pancreas, which can be caused by gallstones, alcohol consumption, and other factors. It can lead to severe abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, fever, and increased heart rate. A gasless abdomen is seen in acute pancreatitis. Other signs include sentinel loop, renal halo and colon cut-off.
  • Other causes of gasless abdomen on Xray include:
    • A paucity of small bowel gas may be a normal finding in some adults
    • Bowel ischemia
    • Intestinal atresia
    • Ascites
    • Gastroenteritis
    • Large abdominal mass - due to displacement

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ulcerative Colitis: Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease that affects the innermost lining of the large intestine (colon) and rectum. Symptoms include diarrhea, often with blood or pus, abdominal pain, and rectal pain. In children, it may affect growth. A gasless abdomen on X-ray is not a typical feature of ulcerative colitis.

 

Option B. Intussusception: Intussusception is a condition in which a segment of the intestine "telescopes" into another, leading to bowel obstruction. This can cut off the blood supply to the affected portion of the intestine. It is one of the most common abdominal emergencies affecting children under two. Classic symptoms include intermittent abdominal pain, "currant jelly" stools, and a palpable "sausage-shaped" mass in the abdomen. While it can lead to changes in an abdominal X-ray like dilated small bowel loops, a gasless abdomen is not the primary diagnostic feature of intussusception.

 

Option D. Crohn's Disease: Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, from mouth to anus. Symptoms can include abdominal pain, severe diarrhea, fatigue, weight loss, and malnutrition. Inflammation caused by Crohn's disease can involve different areas of the digestive tract in different people. Unlike acute pancreatitis, a gasless abdomen is not a primary feature seen with Crohn's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A gasless abdomen on X-ray is commonly associated with acute pancreatitis in children presenting with severe abdominal pain and vomiting. This condition should be considered when evaluating similar clinical presentations.

choices.text: No dose adjustment is required
Add tenofovir 150 mg in the morning
Add lamivudine 300 mg in the morning
Add dolutegravir 50 mg in the morning

questions.text: A patient with history of HIV was started on anti-retroviral therapy consisting of lamivudine 300 mg, tenofovir 150 mg and dolutegravir 50 mg once daily at night. Few weeks later, he developed tuberculosis and was started on anti-tubercular drugs. Which of the following dose adjustment may be required in this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Add dolutegravir 50 mg in the morning

 

Adjustment of ARV regimen with concomitant ATT:

 

  • When a patient already on 2NRTIs + 1NNRTI (EFV)–based regimen has to be given 2HRZE + 4HRE–based ATT for the newly detected TB, same ART regimen can be continued without any modification.
  • When a patient already on 2NRTIs + DTG–based regimen has to be given Rifampicin-based ATT for the newly detected TB, same ART regimen can be continued. However, since co-administered rifampicin reduces bioavailability of DTG, which can be overcome by an additional tablet of DTG 50 mg (at an interval of 12 hours with the regular dose of DTG) till the completion of ATT. Once the ATT is completed, additional tablet of DTG 50 mg should be stopped 2 weeks after stoppage of Rifampicin-containing treatment regimen.
  • When a patient already on 2NRTIs + PI–based regimen develops TB, ART regimen has to be modified if 2HREZ + 4HRE–based ATT is co-administered.
    • If the patient has not taken DTG earlier, patient is shifted to 2 NRTIs + DLG-based regimen with twice daily DTG as discussed in last section
    • If DLG cannot be given due to any reason and boosted PIs need to continued, then rifampicin should be replaced by rifabutin

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients on a dolutegravir-based regimen who start rifampicin-based anti-tubercular therapy, an additional dose of dolutegravir 50 mg should be taken in the morning (12 hours apart from the regular dose) to maintain effective drug levels and manage HIV effectively.

questions.text: A 38-year-old chef presented with complaints of leg pain and swelling. Upon examination, he was diagnosed with varicose veins. Further examination revealed the presence of skin eczema and lipodermatosclerosis. According to the CEAP classification system, He would be classified as: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) C4

 

Explanation of the CEAP Classification:

 

The CEAP classification is a system used to categorize venous disease based on clinical, etiologic, anatomic, and pathophysiologic criteria. Here's a breakdown:

 

  • C: Clinical classification
  • E: Etiologic classification
  • A: Anatomic classification
  • P: Pathophysiologic classification

 

The "C" or clinical classification is divided as follows:

 

  • C0: No visible or palpable signs of venous disease.
  • C1: Telangiectasias or reticular veins.
  • C2: Varicose veins.
  • C3: Edema.
  • C4: Skin changes without ulceration. This is further divided into:
    • C4a: Pigmentation or eczema.
    • C4b: Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche.
    • C4c: Corona phlebectatica
  • C5: Skin changes with healed ulceration.
  • C6: Skin changes with active ulceration.

 

In summary, the patient's symptoms of varicose veins combined with skin changes such as eczema and lipodermatosclerosis correspond to the C4 classification in the CEAP system.

questions.text: Which among the following is not true according to case-control study? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cause to effect design

 

Explanation:

 

A case-control study is a retrospective study that looks backward in time, starting with the outcome (disease) and then investigating potential exposures or risk factors that may have contributed to the disease. It is an effect-to-cause study design. Case-control studies are particularly useful for studying rare diseases, as they allow researchers to identify a sufficient number of cases without requiring a large cohort.

 

Due to the retrospective nature of the study, incidence rates cannot be calculated directly. Instead, the strength of the association between exposure and outcome is measured using the odds ratio, which is calculated using the formula –

 

2 × 2 table

 

 

Odds Ratio (Cross Product Ratio) = ad/bc

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. "Effect to cause design" is a true statement about case-control studies, as they start with the disease (effect) and work backwards to identify potential causes (exposures).

 

Option B. "Used to study Rare Disease" is also a true statement. Case-control studies are well-suited for investigating rare diseases because they allow researchers to identify a sufficient number of cases without requiring a large cohort, which would be impractical and costly.

 

Option C. "Odds ratio can be calculated" is correct. In case-control studies, the incidence rate cannot be directly calculated, so the strength of the association between exposure and outcome is measured using the odds ratio.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Case-control studies are retrospective, effect-to-cause study designs that are particularly useful for investigating rare diseases and calculating odds ratios to measure the strength of association between exposures and outcomes.

questions.text: What is the site for needle insertion in emergency thoracocentesis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Upper border of lower rib

 

In emergency thoracocentesis, the needle is inserted along the upper border of the lower rib to avoid injury to the intercostal vessels and nerve, which are located along the lower border of the upper rib.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lower border of lower rib: This option is incorrect because it still risks injuring intercostal vessels and nerves.

 

Option C. Lower border of upper rib: This option is incorrect because the intercostal vessels and nerve are located here, increasing the risk of injury.

 

Option D. Middle of intercostal space: This option is incorrect because it does not provide a clear anatomical landmark, increasing the risk of accidental injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For thoracocentesis, always insert the needle along the upper border of the lower rib to avoid damaging the intercostal vessels and nerves located at the lower border of the upper rib.
